description: From French pasquinade, from Pasquin + -ade, modelled on Italian pasquinata, from Latin pascha, from Hebrew פסח‎.

entries.meaning: A lampoon, originally as published in public; a satire or libel on someone.
examples: I thought the whole tale would shortly be served up in racy pasquinade – but Catherine, who might have said anything, didn't say a word.

verbs.description: pasquinade (third-person singular simple present pasquinades, present participle pasquinading, simple past and past participle pasquinaded)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To satirize (someone) by using a pasquinade.
examples: Chantilly was a quondam cobbler of the Rue St. Denis, who, becoming stage-mad, had attempted the rôle of Xerxes, in Crébillon's tragedy so called, and been notoriously Pasquinaded for his pains.
